In Moscow today, hundreds of demonstrators defied thousands of Russian riot police and staged an anti-government rally in a downtown square.
At the head of the protest called the Dissenter's March was Garry Kasparov, the former chess champion turned political activist.
Moscow authorities detained Kasparov and at least 170 other protesters.
Officials had denied them permission to demonstrate in the square.
NPR's Gregory Feifer was at today's demonstration and he joins me now.
Greg, would you tell us please about the scene in today's rally.
You've been reporting that Russian police mounted a massive show of force.
That's right.
There were military trucks.
There were riot police blocking off the central streets.

It was impossible to get to central Pushkin Square where the members of the Other Russia opposition coalition said that they had wanted to stage a protest against the administration of President Vladimir Putin.
From what you saw, Greg, and what you heard, how intense did this rally get?
Well, the most intensity was coming from the police.
And where I was, police were pushing into the crowd, pushing them back, even in a place that was sanctioned for the opposition groups to protest, that they had the right to protest there.
I heard lots of witnesses talk about beatings - that police were beating bystanders with batons.

Other reporters told me that they saw police surging into crowds of protesters and pulling them by their hair to arrest them, putting their hands in their mouths and yanking them out of the crowd to arrest them as well.
Now this is the latest in a string of protests by the opposition group led by Kasparov called the Other Russia.
What's the program and how much support did they enjoy?
Well, Other Russia says that they are different from other opposition groups because they don't have an ideological platform.
It's a group that unites very disparate organizations, liberal politicians and communist politicians.
And they have started having these demonstrations last year.
This is the second one in Moscow.
There was one in St. Petersburg last month where 5,000 people came out on the streets.
The police violently broke that one up.
This one didn't even get a chance to get started.
But this is really the center now of opposition to President Vladimir Putin - these marches.
And one is going to take place tomorrow in St. Petersburg as well.
Now, Garry Kasparov has, of course, been very outspoken.
He was detained today and then later released.
Was he charged of anything?
Yes, he was charged with disturbing the peace, essentially.
He was fined a thousand rubles, which is about $40.
So what did Kasparov say when he got out of court?
He said that Russia has reached a new level of authoritarianism.
He said that the authorities aren't even pretending to follow the law.
Where do you see this all heading?
It really seems as if things are coming to some kind of a hit(ph).

Most people believe that the government is cracking down on any dissent ahead of key parliamentary elections this December, and most important, presidential election is next year when Putin has to step down.
Most Russians also believe that whoever Putin names as his favorite successor will almost certainly win the vote.
So there is a lot of questioning about why this is necessary.
There's really no clear answer as to why several thousand protesters who don't have much public support aren't allowed to protest.
Some believed that the authorities have literally gone off their heads that they just won't tolerate any kind of criticism out of principle.
NPR's Gregory Feifer in Moscow.
Thank you very much.
You're welcome.

Prompted by reports of 25 deaths in a four year period, mostly in children, the FDA initially asked the committee only for advice on how to study the safety of the drugs.
It's hard to study the safety of a drug once it's on the market.
Drug companies don't want to spend the money.
Patients don't want to be randomly assigned to get or not get a drug they may feel they need.
Looking back through tens of thousands of patient records to see if there's a pattern is laborious.
Nissen says a warning is needed now, because millions of people, including about 2.5 million children, are taking these drugs.
Why are physicians so willing to give the drugs?
Well, it's because they think the drugs have no risks.
And we felt we had to weigh in on rebalancing the understanding of benefit and risk.
The FDA is also hearing from Capitol Hill.
Republican Senator Chuck Grassley of Iowa earlier this week wrote a letter to the agency, urging it to take action.
On the other side, the agency is hearing from psychiatrists like David Fassler, a clinical professor at the University of Vermont.
He says while patients should be warned there may be a risk, the drugs are valuable in treating the inattentiveness, over-activity and impulsivity that mark ADHD.
He says part of the risk-benefit equation is the risk of not treating.

ADHD is associated with a significant increase in the risk of accidents, including serious car accidents with permanent disability, and an increase in the incidence of substance abuse in adolescents when it's not treated.
And when people get appropriate treatment, it significantly reduces the risk of these serious accidents and of substance abuse.
Sorting this all out is likely to take awhile.
Robert Temple is a top official with the FDA.
I think it's quite likely that while we're considering this, we'll get to the next meeting, which includes pediatric psychiatrists and pediatricians and we'll take what they think into account also.
